flow.descriptionCdata:
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.07bf611b-ef7f-43e1-82a0-29a960de6bd2.prompt=Enter a value for service f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.0b2382f1-3e52-45de-8d30-2d83306fc51e.callout=Restarts the selected Windows service f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.1274dc07-0a8a-4b00-be6b-11d46be251c2.callout=Detects the operating system. f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.4a03d7d9-f4cb-4e7a-a25c-94ae6a9f9379.callout=Checks the status of the service after the restart f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.4b4ec636-f505-4940-8a5c-fc2770c4669e.callout=Lists all available services on the host f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.51b7a162-5574-4c1c-bff4-09776be8fbc5.description=
Runs a command, allowing you to specify whether it runs locally (no port to be specified), via SSH, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
    host - The host name or IP address.
    port - The port number used to connect to the host.
    username - The user name used to connect.
    password - The password associated with the  input. If using a private key file, this is the passphrase for the file.
    protocol - The protocol used to run the command. 
Examples\: SSH, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC, local, WMI, NASConnectTelnet, HPOM
    timeout - The time to wait for the command to complete (in milliseconds). Increase this value if you are getting incomplete output results or a timeout.
Default value\: 90000
    command - The command to run.
    arguments - The arguments to pass to the command.
    environment - Specifies the environment variables and values that need to be defined when running the command.
    startDir - The path to the starting directory.
    pty - Specifies whether to use pty (used by SSH, GlobalShell)
Valid values\: true, false
    privateKeyFile - The path to the private key file, relative to ICONCLUDE_HOME on the RAS host (used by SSH, GlobalShell).
    sasHost - The host on which to run the ROSH command.
    sasHostUsername - The user name used to run the ROSH command on .
    usernamePrompt - The prompt message for the user name. Used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'.
    passwordPrompt - The prompt message for the password associated with the < usernamePrompt > input. Used by the Telnet protocol.  When used by the 'NASConnectTelnet' protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'
    outputPath - The network accessible path where to store the temporary files. If you do not specify this input, it points to '\\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible, change it to use another share to which the host local system account has write access. By default, the path needs to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    nasDevice - The NAS device on which to run the command when using the 'NASConnect' protocol.
    nasDeviceConsoleMode - The NAS device console mode used to run the command scripts running the command on the specified NAS device. If you leave this input empty, command scripts are not used, and the connections to the NAS device and the command are issued directly in the console. This is not recommended. Due to error handling capabilities limitation, the result might be a success even if the command failed to run. You can find the values for this input in the NAS web interface, as a drop-down list when creating a new command script (for example, Cisco IOS enable).
    hpomNode - The node on which to run the command.
    hpomProtocol - The protocol used to communicate with HPOM (HTTP or HTTPS).
    characterSet - The name of the character set used for stream encoding and decoding between the RAS and target machine.
Default value\: UTF-8 (used by SSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC)
Examples\: SJIS,EUC-JP, UTF-8

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Used to determine the operation response, specifying whether the operation is successful or not.
    stdOut - The standard output (STDOUT) of the command.
    stdErr - The standard error (STDERR) of the command.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
Telnet protocol - Since telnet is shell protocol, not a remote execution protocol, the response is always  successful if the command is ran in the remote shell.  The return code of the specified command cannot be determined in this protocol.  If you must use the telnet protocol with this operation, make sure to check the command results. Consider using the SSH or REXEC protocol instead.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.5b73fba5-324e-424e-b968-3144cd707629.callout=Checks the status of the service after the restart f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.5cd2f420-8f8e-4063-95a5-ba374ffa4e2c.description=
Restart a service or daemon on a target Linux machine.

Inputs
    host - The target linux host on which to restart the service.
    username - The user to connect to the host.
    password - The password to connect to the host.
    service - The name of the service to be restarted.

Responses
    success - The flow completed successfully and the service was restarted.
    failure - The flow failed to restart the service.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.6060d07e-9d18-4e37-a7a4-43ed1d93ed15.prompt=Enter a value for service f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.7f9321aa-aa73-489d-9aa9-20d52dc5ed97.callout=This is an agnostic flow that restarts a Windows service or Linux daemon. This flow works both on local and remote machines, and is compatible with both Windows and Linux operating systems. On Windows hosts, the service must be set to start in Automatic or Manual mode. All other services that the given service depends on will also be restarted. In order for the flow to work, the service Server (on Windows hosts) or LanManServer (on Linux hosts) must be running. f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.8df3a142-389f-4a5c-85a1-f2fd5c46afed.description=
Returns a list of all the available services on the target host. This flow works both on local and or remote machines, and is compatible with both Windows and Linux systems.

Inputs
    operatingSystem - The operating system name as returned by the operations "Operating System Detector".
    host - The target host on which to look for all the services.
    username - The user to connect to the host.
    password - The password to connect to the host.

Results
    servicesList - The list of available services on the target host, separated by comma.

Responses
    success - The flow completed successfully and the list of services was retrieved.
    failure - The flow failed to retrieve the list of services.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.9c19d06f-6a6c-420a-8003-3fd3ee2034b9.callout=Lists all available services on the host f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.9c9b841d-b336-4f61-b9ea-de38e014844d.prompt=Enter a value for service f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.9cb022b2-0251-43fe-9804-147048e25561.description=
 Detects the operating system that is running on the specified host.

Inputs\:
    host - The host to connect to.
    username - The username to use when connecting.
    password - The password to use when connecting.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. The name and the version of the operating system.
    osName - The completely returned string of the OS name.
    version - The operating systems version.
    hostName - The host name the remote computer reports for itself.
    enterprise - 'true' if the operating system is an enterprise edition
    server - 'true' if the operating system is a server edition
    professional - 'true' if the operating system is a professional edition.
    standard - 'true' if the operating system is a standard edition.

Responses\:
    windows - Remote host is running a version of windows.
    linux - Remote host is running linux.
    solaris - Remote host is running solaris.
    other unix - Remote host appears to be unix based, but is an unknown variant.
    failure - System could not determine remote hosts operating system.

Notes\:
1. The enterprise, server, professional and standard results give more details about what version of windows is detected and are always set to 'false' if a unix system is being run.
2. The operation returns the output of a uname -a for unix based hosts, and the results of osName and version WMI queries for a windows host.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.b73975fc-f2d5-460e-96d7-5d690f65cea8.description=
Compares two strings, returning a true response if and only if they contain the same sequence of characters. A null string is considered to be equal to an empty string.

Inputs\:
string1 - The first string.
string2 - The second string.
ignoreCase - If set to 'true', then the comparison ignores case considerations. The two strings are considered equal ignoring case if they are of the same length and corresponding characters in the two strings are equal ignoring case. If set to any value other than 'true', then the strings must match exactly to be considered equal.

responses\:
true - If the two strings are equal
false - If the two strings are not equal
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.c911672b-2c3b-45c3-97a8-7a09568c02e8.description=
Restarts a Windows service. This service must be set to start in Automatic or Manual mode. Services set to Disabled cannot be restarted using this operation. All the services that the given service depends on will also be restarted. 
The given host must have the Server service (LanManServer) running in order for the flow to work. For this reason, if you try to restart this service the flow will stop it, but won`t be able to start it again. 

Inputs\:
host 	- The host on which the service resides.
service 	- The service to restart.
altuser 	- The username to use when authenticating with host (Example\: domain\username).
altpass 	- The password to use when authenticating with host.

Responses\:
success 		- Service restarted successfully.
failure 		- Service could not be restarted.
service failed to restart 	- Service was stopped, but would not restart.
service didn't stop 	- Service failed to stop.

Extra Results\:
serviceRestartResult - The return code of the service restart operation.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.d54f5dbe-662d-4e01-a8c9-b7ad1e6397f9.description=
Get the current status of a Windows service.

Inputs\:
host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
service - Name of service to change.
user - Username to use for thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
password - Password of the user.

Responses\:
service paused - The service is currently paused.
service running - The service is currently running.
service stopped - The service is currently stopped.
service pending - The service is currently pending.
failure - There was a problem getting the state of the service.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.description=
This is an agnostic flow that restarts a service or daemon. This flow works both on localhost and remote machines, and is compatible with both Windows and Linux systems.
For Windows this service must be set to start in Automatic or Manual mode. Services set to Disabled cannot be restarted using this operation. All the services that the given service depends on will also be restarted. The given host must have the Server service (LanManServer) running in order for the flow to work. For this reason, if you try to restart this service the flow will stop it, but won`t be able to start it again. 

Inputs
    host - The target system on which to restart the service.
    user - The username to connect to the target host.
    password - The password to connect to the target host.
    service - The name of the service to be restarted. If this is not provided, the flow will search for all the available services on the host, and promt the user to select one of them to be restarted.

Responses
    success - The flow completed and the service was restarted successfully.
    failure - The flow failed to restart the service.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.e97151c9-2c3a-41a3-84e2-c42a78343abb.callout=Restarts the selected Linux Service f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.f3e5fc31-2823-4bde-91c5-bef7d3a9c583.description=
Returns a list of all the available services on the target host. This flow works both on local and or remote machines, and is compatible with both Windows and Linux systems.

Inputs
    operatingSystem - The operating system name as returned by the operations "Operating System Detector".
    host - The target host on which to look for all the services.
    username - The user to connect to the host.
    password - The password to connect to the host.

Results
    servicesList - The list of available services on the target host, separated by comma.

Responses
    success - The flow completed successfully and the list of services was retrieved.
    failure - The flow failed to retrieve the list of services.
f864d20d-7291-4052-a100-4bc0fba91817.f70cb1d5-7ca0-4b9a-992f-1179a105b921.description=
Compares two strings, returning a true response if and only if they contain the same sequence of characters. A null string is considered to be equal to an empty string.

Inputs\:
string1 - The first string.
string2 - The second string.
ignoreCase - If set to 'true', then the comparison ignores case considerations. The two strings are considered equal ignoring case if they are of the same length and corresponding characters in the two strings are equal ignoring case. If set to any value other than 'true', then the strings must match exactly to be considered equal.

responses\:
true - If the two strings are equal
false - If the two strings are not equal
flow.name: Restart Service

scriptlet.name: Step Service Status Linux in Flow Restart Service (4032d4b6-579e-4f83-b381-f1322b94ccd3)
